paper_abstract: A large variety of hybrid computational aeroacoustics (CAA) approaches exist differing from each other ill the way the source region is modeled. In the way the equations are used 10 compute, the acoustic waves and In the way the coupling between source and acoustic Propagation regions is made This paper makes comparison between some commonly numerical methods for aeroacoustic applications The aerodynamically generated tonal noise by it flow over it 2D rectangular cavity is investigated. Two different cavities are studied In the first cavity (L/D=4, M =0 5), the sound field is dominated by the cavity wake mode and its higher harmonics, originating from a periodical vortex S111CCILlIng.11 the Cavity leading edge In the second cavity (L/D=2. M=0.6), shearlayer mades. due to flow-acoustic interaction phenomena. generate tile major components in the noise spectrum. Source domain modeling is carried out using a second-order finite-volume large eddy simulation Propagation equations, taking into account convection and refraction effects. are solved using, high-order finite-difference shemes for the linearized Euler equations and (lie acoustic I)perturbation equations Both schemes are compared with each other for various coupling methods between source region and acoustic region. Conventional acoustic analogies and Kirchhoff methods are rewritten for the various propagation equations and used to obtain near-field acoustic results. The accuracy of the various coupling- methods in identifying the noise-generating mechanisms is evaluated In this way, this paper provides more insight into the practical Use of various hybrid CAA techniques to predict the acrodynamically generated sound field by flow over rectanaular cavities. paper_title: Toward accurate hybrid prediction techniques for cavity flow noise applications
